#India
```{r}
# Load necessary libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
library(tidyr)

# Create a data frame with the given population data
population_data <- data.frame(
  Age_Group = c("0-14", "15-19", "20-24", "25-29", "30-34", "35-39", "40-44", "45-49", "50-54", "55-59", "60-64", "65-69", "70-74", "75-79", "80+"),
  Male_2011 = c(207776, 63994, 57845, 51425, 46065, 42166, 37672, 32032, 25914, 20940, 17515, 13615, 10546, 5471, 2943),
  Female_2011 = c(190538, 57770, 53769, 49655, 45198, 40959, 35670, 29722, 24162, 20466, 17844, 13808, 10837, 5377, 3582),
  Male_2016 = c(202313, 67223, 63521, 57272, 50782, 45318, 41280, 36602, 30738, 24403, 19133, 15198, 11002, 7703, 4496),
  Female_2016 = c(184133, 60871, 57356, 53357, 49250, 44787, 40497, 35107, 29016, 23307, 19288, 16114, 11723, 8367, 5161),
  Male_2021 = c(195942, 64862, 66770, 62944, 56614, 50027, 44450, 40204, 35235, 29082, 22465, 16823, 12546, 8269, 6637),
  Female_2021 = c(177343, 59420, 60474, 56956, 52961, 48836, 44315, 39903, 34331, 28062, 22079, 17583, 13904, 9294, 7970),
  Male_2026 = c(190259, 61038, 64463, 66201, 62271, 55840, 49144, 43374, 38803, 33466, 26934, 19954, 14104, 9615, 8205),
  Female_2026 = c(171127, 56562, 59066, 60085, 56562, 52547, 48361, 43710, 39082, 33282, 26700, 20300, 15394, 11266, 10357),
  Male_2031 = c(180359, 61878, 60719, 63970, 65561, 61499, 54936, 48049, 41968, 36980, 31158, 24126, 16941, 10980, 9897),
  Female_2031 = c(163787, 55038, 56263, 58725, 59700, 56154, 52074, 47746, 42866, 37965, 31787, 24718, 17981, 12701, 13137),
  Male_2036 = c(170499, 59432, 61671, 60367, 63466, 64879, 60631, 53839, 46615, 40135, 34600, 28119, 20703, 13358, 11670),
  Female_2036 = c(155610, 53270, 54786, 55972, 58383, 59299, 55678, 51451, 46881, 41721, 36373, 29601, 22111, 15053, 15850)
)

# Convert data to long format for ggplot
population_long <- population_data %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = -Age_Group, names_to = "Year_Gender", values_to = "Population") %>%
  separate(Year_Gender, into = c("Gender", "Year"), sep = "_", extra = "merge") %>%
  mutate(Population = ifelse(Gender == "Male", -Population, Population))  # Make male values negative for pyramid

# Plot the population pyramid for all years
ggplot(population_long, aes(x = Age_Group, y = Population, fill = Gender)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", width = 0.8) +
  coord_flip() +  # Flip for pyramid style
  scale_y_continuous(labels = abs) +  # Show absolute values on y-axis
  facet_wrap(~Year, ncol = 2) +  # Create separate pyramids for each year
  labs(title = "India",
       x = "Age Group",
       y = "Population (in thousands)",
       fill = "Gender") +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("Male" = "#ce4a37", "Female" = "#38406b")) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))  # Rotate x-axis labels for readability

# Define age groups
youth_groups <- c("0-14")
working_age_groups <- c("15-19", "20-24", "25-29", "30-34", "35-39", "40-44", "45-49", "50-54", "55-59")
elderly_groups <- c("60-64", "65-69", "70-74", "75-79", "80+")

# Function to calculate dependency ratios
calculate_dependency_ratios <- function(year) {
  youth_pop <- sum(population_data %>% filter(Age_Group %in% youth_groups) %>% 
                     select(starts_with(paste0("Male_", year)), starts_with(paste0("Female_", year))) %>% rowSums())
  
  working_age_pop <- sum(population_data %>% filter(Age_Group %in% working_age_groups) %>% 
                           select(starts_with(paste0("Male_", year)), starts_with(paste0("Female_", year))) %>% rowSums())
  
  elderly_pop <- sum(population_data %>% filter(Age_Group %in% elderly_groups) %>% 
                       select(starts_with(paste0("Male_", year)), starts_with(paste0("Female_", year))) %>% rowSums())
  
  dependency_ratio <- (youth_pop + elderly_pop) / working_age_pop
  youth_dependency_ratio <- youth_pop / working_age_pop
  elderly_dependency_ratio <- elderly_pop / working_age_pop
  
  return(data.frame(
    Year = year,
    Dependency_Ratio = dependency_ratio,
    Youth_Dependency_Ratio = youth_dependency_ratio,
    Elderly_Dependency_Ratio = elderly_dependency_ratio
  ))
}

# Years for calculation
years <- c("2011", "2016", "2021", "2026", "2031", "2036")

# Apply the function to all years
dependency_ratios <- do.call(rbind, lapply(years, calculate_dependency_ratios))

# Print the results
print(dependency_ratios)
```

```{r}
age_long <- age_data %>%

# Load necessary library
library(dplyr)

# Function to calculate dependency ratios
calculate_dependency_ratios <- function(data, year) {
  # Extract relevant columns
  total_population <- rowSums(data[, paste0(c("Male_", "Female_"), year)])
  
  # Define age group indices
  youth_index <- which(data$Age_Group == "0-14")
  working_age_index <- which(data$Age_Group %in% c("15-19", "20-24", "25-29", "30-34", 
                                                   "35-39", "40-44", "45-49", "50-54", "55-59"))
  elderly_index <- which(data$Age_Group %in% c("60-64", "65-69", "70-74", "75-79", "80+"))
  
  # Calculate population sums for each category
  youth_population <- sum(total_population[youth_index])
  working_age_population <- sum(total_population[working_age_index])
  elderly_population <- sum(total_population[elderly_index])
  
  # Compute dependency ratios
  dependency_ratio <- (youth_population + elderly_population) / working_age_population
  youth_dependency_ratio <- youth_population / working_age_population
  elderly_dependency_ratio <- elderly_population / working_age_population
  
  # Return results as a named vector
  return(c(Dependency_Ratio = dependency_ratio, 
           Youth_Dependency_Ratio = youth_dependency_ratio, 
           Elderly_Dependency_Ratio = elderly_dependency_ratio))
}

# Define the years to calculate dependency ratios
years <- c("2011", "2016", "2021", "2026", "2031", "2036")

# Create a table with dependency ratios for all years
dependency_ratios_table <- as.data.frame(t(sapply(years, function(y) calculate_dependency_ratios(age_data, y))))

# Add year column
dependency_ratios_table <- dependency_ratios_table %>%
  mutate(Year = years) %>%
  select(Year, everything())

# Print the table
print(dependency_ratios_table)


```

```{r}
calculate_dependency_ratios <- function(data, year) {
  # Extract relevant columns
  total_population <- rowSums(data[, paste0("Year_", year, "_", c("Male", "Female"))])
  
  # Define age group indices
  young_age_index <- which(data$Age_Group == "0-14")
  working_population_index <- which(data$Age_Group %in% c("15-19", "20-24", "25-29", "30-34", 
                                                          "35-39", "40-44", "45-49", "50-54", "55-59"))
  senior_population_index <- which(data$Age_Group %in% c("60-64", "65-69", "70-74", "75-79", "80+"))
  
  # Calculate population sums for each category
  young_population <- sum(total_population[young_age_index])
  working_population <- sum(total_population[working_population_index])
  senior_population <- sum(total_population[senior_population_index])
  
  # Compute dependency ratios
  overall_dependency <- (young_population + senior_population) / working_population
  youth_dependency <- young_population / working_population
  elderly_dependency <- senior_population / working_population
  
  # Return results as a named vector
  return(c(Overall_Dependency = overall_dependency, 
           Youth_Dependency = youth_dependency, 
           Elderly_Dependency = elderly_dependency))
}
```
